title: Sunk Cost and Escalation
content: Sunk cost fallacy makes you continue a course of action because of past investment rather than future prospects. 'We've come this far' isn't a reason to continue if conditions no longer support the plan. Evaluate decisions based on what's ahead, not what's behind. Past costs are irrelevant to future decisions.

mcq.question: You're 80% through a procedure when conditions change, making completion risky. You've invested significant time. What should guide your decision?

options.B: Evaluate whether continuing is justified by current conditions, ignoring time already spent
options.C: Speed up to finish before conditions worsen
options.D: Continue since stopping wastes the effort

mcq.explanation: Time spent is a sunk cost and irrelevant to the forward decision. Only current conditions and future prospects should determine whether to continue or stop.

openQuestions: When has sunk cost influenced you to continue something you should have stopped?
How do you recognize when you're committing to a losing course?
